descript.abstract: The physical location of Locks and Dams maintained by the US Army Corp of Engineers along Navigable Waterways (Mississippi River) in the State of Minnesota.
descript.purpose: To create a spatial representation of Lock and Dam loctions in the State of Minnesota.

idinfo.useconst: By accepting this data, the user agrees not to transmit this data or provide access to it or any part of it to another party or the public unless the user shall include with the data a copy of the disclaimer. The disclaimer can be found in Section 6 of this document (Distribution Liability).

theme.themekey: transportation, inland, Waters, navigation, navigable water, River, and Routes

stdorder.ordering: The data may be requested from the Contact person listed in the metadata.

cntinfo.cntpos: Data Systems and Coordination Section Director

horizpa.horizpar: Location accuracy for features derived from USGS 7.5-minute quadrangles cannot be assumed to exceed National Map Accuracy Standards for 1:24,000 scale maps (+/- 40 feet or 12 meters). Accuracy of updates based on imagery is dependent on the resolution of the imagery used. Imagery used for updates would represent the best imagery available at the time of the update.

lineage.procstep:
The original data source for the MnDOT Basemap Roads features was the USGS 1:24,000-scale USGS 7.5-minute quadrangle maps.
During the time period 1990-1995, the Roads and other MnDOT BaseMap data layers were digitized from USGS 7.5-minute quadrangles using MicroStation CADD. A total of 1745 quadrangles were digitized. For any given area, MnDOT used the most recent quadrangle available at that time. The digital MicroStation CADD files were converted from State Plane Coordinates to UTM and then converted into ARC/INFO coverages. The ARC/INFO files were merged into statewide, seamless coverages and then attributes were added.
Beginning in March, 1999, the Roads features were checked and updated, using 1997 digital orthophotos for Anoka, Carver, Dakota, Hennepin, Ramsey, Scott and Washington Counties and 1991 digital orthophotos for the remaining 80 counties.
The Roads features layer is updated continuously as information comes in to the Office of Transportation System Management. The Minnesota Trunk Highway (TH), County State Aid System (CSAH), and Municipal State Aid System (MSAS) alignments and route data are improved each year through our annual status process. Changes to roads come from several sources including county engineers, city engineers, GIS personnel and the MnDOT State Aid office (which manages county state aid highways and municipal state aid streets), the most recent aerial photos available, and construction plans. It originated as a coverage with the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers. Then MnDOT extracted the data that lay within the state boundary, creating a point layer where the locks intersect the navigation channel. The river true mile value is derived from the navigable waters feature class. It originated as a coverage with the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers.
